channel.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
channel.description:
Hi guys, I just finished Half-Life 1 and what a beautiful and amazing game that was. The thing is I have questions about the ending. First of all I chose not to work with the GMan and eventually found myself in hundreds of aliens and credits afterwards. However after the credits ended there was this black screen and I actually waited looking at that black screen for like 20 mins because I thought the game didn't really ended. Interestingly the icons of the ammo and health and stuff was still on the screen and actually when I push jump button there was the hitting-to-floor noise like you are still in the game. So what actually happened? Did Freeman died or what? Did I miss something? And what would have happened if I accepted Gman's offer?
Thanks :slight_smile:

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: Surplus
item.description:
Ramirezoid:

I have always seen it as ambiguous which ending is ‘canon’. It’s fiction. Gordon could have mowed through about half of those agrunts before passing out and entering stasis behind the scenes.

With all of your no weapons because he took them for being government property.

Read full topic

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: TheGkbrk
item.description:
Oh, thanks everyone for clean explanations. Now I’ll play Half-Life 2, looking forward to it.

Read full topic

He is really not… at liberty to say.

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Yes, it’s possible that, if you refuse G-Man’s offer, he teleports you to the agrunt room and then puts you into stasis before they can attack you, to show you that you really didn’t have any choice in the matter. Either do what G-Man says or… well…

Read full topic

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: Ramirezoid
item.description:
I have always seen it as ambiguous which ending is ‘canon’. It’s fiction. Gordon could have mowed through about half of those agrunts before passing out and entering stasis behind the scenes.

Read full topic

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: Crypt
item.description:
I don’t think that’s what he was asking.
Your game glitched out, it was supposed to end after the credits. In that (non-canon) ending; Yes, Freeman dies (or it’s implied, anyway. Unarmed Freeman vs. dozens/hundreds of agrunts? Psh.).

If you were to accept the offer, you’d just get a black screen w/ a few more G-man words and go to credits. Story-wise Freeman is put into stasis roughly 2 decades, which then resumes with Half-Life 2.

Read full topic

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: Orpheon
item.description:
IOW, the choice is an illusion since there’s only one “real” option, which is to work for G-Man, since the alternative is death by those alien grunts. Although, it could be argued that if you really, deeply objected to G-Man’s offer, death would be a real option as well. In any case, Half-Life 2 naturally assumes you took his offer and kept living to fight another day, so that is the “correct” option.

Read full topic

item.title: About Half-Life 1's Ending
item.dc:creator: JohnWorfin
item.description:
It is a Hobson’s choice.

Read full topic
